facts.text: Petitions are connected with petitions under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: These are companynected with petitions under Article 226 of the Constitution. They raise companymon questions of law and fact. Hence they can be companysidered in a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Petitioners are serving as Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks in the Northern Railway.

anchor.surface_text: In these petitions, the petitioners who are serving as Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks in the Northern Railway, seek the following reliefs A writ of mandamus to Respondent No.1  General Manager, Northern Railway  requiring him to withdraw his order dated November 3, 1965,

facts.text: Railway Board communication No. E NG 63 PMI-52 dated February 29, 1964 prescribed channel of promotion for Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Board by its companymunication No. E  NG  63 PMI-52 dated February 29, 1964 to the General Manager, All Indian Railways prescribed a channel of promotion for Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks, who up till then had numberchannel of promotion.

facts.text: Under the scheme, distribution of posts in every 20: 15 Enquiry cum Reservation Clerks Rs.150-240, 2 Assistant Reservation Supervisors Rs.205-280, 2 Reservation Supervisors Rs.250-380, 1 Chief Reservation Inspector Rs.370-475.

anchor.surface_text: That letter companyveyed the following decision of the Railway Board The total number of higher grade posts of Assistant Reservation Supervisors in the scale of Rs. 205-280 AS , Reservation Supervisors in the scale of Rs.250-380  AS  and Chief Reservation Inspector in the scale of Rs.370-475  AS  shall be 25 per cent of the total number of posts in the cadre. In other words, in every unit of various 20 posts, the distribution of posts in the various categories shall be as under Category No. Of posts Scale of pay Classification Enquiry cum Reservation Clerks 15 Rs.150-240 AS  Selection Assistant Reservation Supervisors 2 Rs.205-280 AS  Non-Selection Reservation Supervisors 2 Rs.250-380 AS  Selection Chief Reservation Inspector 1 Rs. 370-475 AS  Selection.

facts.text: General Manager, Northern Railway, accorded sanction to upgrading: 11 posts CRI Rs.370-475, 18 RS Rs.250-380, 26 ARS Rs.205-280 from 1-4-1964.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the aforementioned companymunication of the Railway Board, the General Manager, Northern Railway, accorded sanction to the upgrading of the following posts from 1-4-1964, in the cadre of Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks. 1. 11 posts as C.R.I. Grade Rs.370 to 475. 2. 18 posts as Reservation Supervisor Grade Rs. 250 to Rs.380. 3. 26 posts as Assistant Reservation Supervisor grade Rs.205 to Rs.280.

facts.text: Railway Board letter No. E NG 62 PMI/91 dated July 10, 1964 prescribed procedure for filling non-gazetted selection posts: panel = existing + anticipated vacancies +25%, anticipated due to normal wastage, currency 2 years.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Board by its letter No. E  NG  62 PMI/91 dated July 10, 1964, prescribed the following procedure for filling up of number-gazetted selection posts The number of persons to be placed on a panel should be equal to the existing and anticipated vacancies plus 25 per cent thereof for unforeseen vacancies. Anticipated vacancies companynote only those which are likely to arise due to numbermal wastage during the currency of the panel. The currency of the panel for number-gazetted selection posts should be two years from the date of approval of the same by the companypetent authority or till exhausted whichever is earlier.

facts.text: General Manager Northern Railway sent communication to Divisional Superintendents on January 22, 1965 for selection for Reservation Supervisor grade Rs.250-380, written test on 13-2-1965.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the Railway Boards letter dated 10-7-1964, the General Manager, Northern Railway, sent the following companymunication to the Divisional Superintendents under him on January 22, 1965 Subject - Selection for the post of Reservation Supervisor grade Rs. 250-380 AS . It has been decided to hold a selection for the post of Reservation Supervisor grade Rs. 250-380 AS . The written test of the staff eligible to appear in the said selection will be companyducted on the respective divisions on which they are employed on 13-2-1965.

facts.text: Written tests held on 13-2-1965 as prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: The tests as prescribed in the above letter were duly held.

facts.text: Selection Committee selected 38 persons including the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The Selection Committee selected 38 persons including the petitioners.

facts.text: Panel names published on August 1, 1965 in Northern Railway Gazette. Petitioners ranked at number 25 or below.

anchor.surface_text: The names of the persons in the panel were published on August 1, 1965, in the Northern Railway Gazette. The petitioners are ranked at number 25 or below.

facts.text: Publication stated retention of names subject to satisfactory work, no right to permanent absorption.

anchor.surface_text: The said numberification further stated that the staff companycerned may please be informed that retention of their names on the panel is subject to their work remaining satisfactory during the currency of the panel. The mere fact that their names are on the list panel will number companyfer upon them any right for permanent absorption as Reservation Supervisors.

facts.text: Senior members who were not selected agitated regarding mode of promotion, questions in Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: After the publication of the panel some of the senior members of the staff who had number been selected appear to have carried on certain agitations as regards the mode prescribed for promotion. In that companynection certain questions also appear to have been put in the Parliament.

facts.text: Railway Board wrote confidential letter to General Manager Northern Railway directing partial cancellation of panel: operate first 24 only, delete remaining 14.

anchor.surface_text: Some time thereafter, it appears, the Railway Board wrote to the General Manager, Northern Railway, the following companyfidential letter The Board have companysidered the matter of great length and observed that your administration have number followed the companyrect procedure... In view of the above, the Board have decided that the panel already published should be operated to the extent of first 24 persons only deleting the names of the remaining 14 persons forthwith.

facts.text: General Manager Northern Railway issued communication deleting names of remaining 14 from panel of 38.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently because of the aforementioned directions of the Board, the General Manager, Northern Railway, issued the following companymunication to the Divisional Superintendents in the Northern Railway Subject - Selection for the post of Reservation Supervisor number designed as Chief Engineer and Res. Clerk grade Rs. 250-380  AS . It has been decided that the panel of 38 persons for the above mentioned post circulated vide this office letter of even No. Dated 7-7-1965, is to be operated upto the first 24 persons only and the names of the remaining 14 persons be treated as deleted from the panel.

facts.text: Names of petitioners removed from the panel.

anchor.surface_text: In view of that companymunication, the names of the petitioners stand removed from the panel.

facts.text: General Manager Northern Railway order dated November 3, 1965 No. 754E/20-II Trip EIC.

anchor.surface_text: requiring him to withdraw his order dated November 3, 1965,  order No. 754E/20-II  Trip   EIC  and to restore the names of the petitioners of the panel as shown in Annexure E to the petition

facts.text: Petitioners allege Railway Board direction under political pressure (mala fides).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners allege that under political pressure, the Railway Board was companypelled to direct the General Manager, Northern Railway to operate the panel upto the first 24 persons only

facts.text: Respondents deny allegation of political pressure or mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation that the interpretation placed by the Railway Board on the expression numbermal wastage was number a bona fide interpretation but one that was given under political pressure is denied by the respondents.

facts.text: Court finds no satisfactory proof of mala fides, allegation unsubstantiated.

anchor.surface_text: Before me, there is numbersatisfactory proof in support of the allegation of mala fides. Hence it must be held that that allegation is unsubstantiated.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, these petitions fail and they are dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioners seek writ of mandamus to withdraw order dated November 3, 1965 and restore panel Annexure E.

anchor.surface_text: seek the following reliefs A writ of mandamus to Respondent No.1  General Manager, Northern Railway  requiring him to withdraw his order dated November 3, 1965,  order No. 754E/20-II  Trip   EIC  and to restore the names of the petitioners of the panel as shown in Annexure E to the petition and to make promotions on the basis of that panel A writ of mandamus to Respondent No. 2  Railway Board  to withdraw its direction and orders to Respondent No.1 to partially cancel the panel shown at Annexure E to the petition

facts.text: Interviews for Delhi area held 16th to 18th February 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The interviews for staff of Delhi area including Delhi Division will be held in this office on 16th to 18th February.

facts.text: Petitioners' efforts to withdraw the communication failed, hence writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Their efforts to get withdrawn the aforementioned companymunication of the General Manager, Northern Railway, have failed. Hence these writ petitions.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Board's interpretation of the expression 'normal wastage' was vitiated by mala fides or political pressure?

anchor.surface_text: The allegation that the interpretation placed by the Railway Board on the expression normal wastage was not a bona fide interpretation but one that was given under political pressure is denied by the respondents. A plea of mala fides is easy to advance but difficult to establish.

issues.text: Whether the interpretation of 'normal wastage' given by the Railway Board is erroneous and whether the General Manager's interpretation was correct?

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that the interpretation of the expression, normal wastage given by the Railway Board, is a wholly erroneous interpretation and the said expression had been correctly interpreted by the General Manager, Northern Railway his interpretation accords with the view taken by the General Managers of other Railways therefore the General Manager, Northern Railway, should not have accepted the interpretation given by the Railway Board.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Board's direction violated Article 14 by discriminating between Northern Railway and other Railways?

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged on behalf of the petitioners that the interpretation of the expression normal wastage given by the Railway Board was confined only to the promotion of Enquiry-Cum-Reservation Clerks of the Northern Railway, that expression had been interpreted in a different manner by the other Railways yet the Railway Board has not chosen to interfere with the selection made by the other Railways not with the selections of Class Iii officials made in the other Departments of the Railways therefore the impugned direction of the Railway Board is violative of Article 14 of the Constitution and consequently it is liable to be struck down.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners were aggrieved persons having a legal right due to inclusion in the panel?

anchor.surface_text: The maintainability of those petitions was challenged by the respondents on the ground that the petitioners cannot be considered as having been aggrieved by the impugned order of the General Manager, Northern Railway. The fact that their names were found in the panel merely gave them a chance of being promoted.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Board's order dated July 10, 1964 has statutory force as a rule under Rule 157 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code framed under Article 309?

anchor.surface_text: There was considerable argument on the question whether the order of the Railway Board contained in its letter dated July 10, 1964, is merely an administrative instruction or whether the same has statutory force. ... Under Rule 157 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code, Volume 1, which are admittedly rules framed under Article 309 of the Constitution, the Railway Board have full powers to make rules of general application to non-Gazetted Railway Servants under their control.

issues.text: Whether the power exercised by the Railway Board is judicial or quasi-judicial?

anchor.surface_text: The power conferred under the order mentioned above is neither a judicial powers nor a quasi-judicial power as contended by the counsel for the petitioners. It is purely an executive power.

issues.text: Whether there is a basis for contending that the impugned order of the General Manager is a rule made under Rule 158 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code?

anchor.surface_text: There is no basis for the contention that the impugned order of the General Manager, Northern Railway, is a rule made under Rule 158 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Board exceeded its authority by interfering with the discretion of the General Manager?

anchor.surface_text: It is also not correct to contend that the Board exceeded its authority in interfering with the discretion of the General Manager, Northern Railway, in issuing the direction in question. Under the order of the Railway Board, dated July 10, 1964, no discretion was given to the General Managers.

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice were violated as the petitioners were not heard before the impugned order?

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged that principles of natural justice were violated inasmuch as the petitioners were not heard before the General Manager, Northern Railway, made the impugned order.

issues.text: Whether the General Manager became functus officio after publishing the panel and was incompetent to issue the impugned order?

anchor.surface_text: Aid was sought from the decision of the Supreme Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers union, , for the contention that the General Manager, Northern Railway, became functus officio, once he published the panel, therefore, he was, not competent to issue the impugned order.

holdings.text: There is no satisfactory proof in support of the allegation of mala fides. Hence it must be held that that allegation is unsubstantiated.

anchor.surface_text: Before me, there is numbersatisfactory proof in support of the allegation of mala fides. Hence it must be held that that allegation is unsubstantiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea of mala fides easy to advance but difficult to establish; allegations vague, denied in affidavits, no proof provided.

holdings.text: The Railway Board is the best authority to interpret the expression 'normal wastage' which it coined, and its interpretation is not wholly unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: I do number see any merit in this companytention. The expression numbermal wastage is number a defined expression. It appears to have been a term companyned by the Railway Board. Therefore, the Railway Board is the best authority to say what it meant by that expression.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expression coined by Railway Board; they are best to interpret; not erroneous or unsustainable.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Article 14; unable to conclude any discrimination between Railways in implementation of July 10, 1964 order.

anchor.surface_text: From the material on record, I am unable to companyclude that any discrimination was made by the Railway Board between the various Railways in the matter of implementation of its order dated July 10, 1964.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No material on record to show discrimination; interpretation of general application binding on all.
